title: All Stars: The Sensational History of Athletics as Entertainment
location: Houghton Library, Harvard Yard, Cambridge
fullLocation: Houghton Library, Harvard Yard, Cambridge
description: Prior to the rise of professional sports in the 20th century, boundaries between sport, theater, and spectacle were blurred. This exhibit explores sports as a mode of performance and entertainment. What connects outstanding athletes across time are attributes such as strength, balance, and nerve—themes around which this exhibition is organized. Athletic stars of yesteryear left an extraordinary legacy in the form of prints, photographs, and other ephemera, and these materials underscore how the appeal of modern sports was built on a shared foundation of skilled athleticism and sensational entertainment. This exhibition was co-curated by Matthew Wittmann and Karintha Lowe of the Harvard Theatre Collection.

title: Edvard Munch: Technically Speaking
location: Harvard Art Museums, 32 Quincy St., Cambridge
fullLocation: Harvard Art Museums, 32 Quincy St., Cambridge
description: Discover the experimental methods of Edvard Munch, who creatively explored materials and techniques across media. A dynamic collaboration between curatorial and conservation experts at the Harvard Art Museums, Edvard Munch: Technically Speaking offers rare insight into the Norwegian artist’s innovative techniques and the recurring themes across his paintings, woodcuts, lithographs, etchings, and combination prints. The Harvard Art Museums house one of the largest and most significant collections of artwork by Munch in the United States, and the exhibition showcases roughly 70 works, including key loans from Munchmuseet, Oslo.

title: The Caribbean: Sea of Resilience
location: Houghton Library, Harvard Yard, Cambridge
fullLocation: Houghton Library, Harvard Yard, Cambridge
description: "The Caribbean: Sea of Resilience" sheds light on Houghton’s holdings of Caribbean materials and the creativity, strength, and history of the Caribbean people. It seeks to honor creators whose art and thought enrich our collection, while bringing to light the stories of those whose voices were long overshadowed by colonial histories. A variety of Caribbean materials can be found at Houghton, ranging from an early map of the region, a document signed by Toussaint L'Ouverture, and a manuscript by renowned Antiguan-American author Jamaica Kincaid. This exhibition was guest curated by Chloe McKain, Class of 2027 and President of the Harvard Caribbean Club.

title: The Punched Card from the Industrial Revolution to the Information Age
location: Houghton Library, Harvard Yard, Cambridge
fullLocation: Houghton Library, Harvard Yard, Cambridge
description: 2025 marks the 300th anniversary of a technology associated with the computer age, but with roots in the Industrial Revolution. In 1725, French silk weaver Basile Bouchon invented the use of a paper tape with punched holes to automate the work of a loom. By the 19th century, punchcard-controlled looms produced sophisticated textiles, including fabric "pages" woven from silk to simulate the leaves of a medieval manuscript. Computing pioneer Charles Babbage first envisioned adapting punched cards to computing; in the early computer age, they were the primary means for data entry and processing. In "Punched Card Methods in Scientific Computation," Wallace Eckert shared his work using punched cards to perform complex calculations such as determining the orbits of planets.

title: The Solomon Collection: Dürer to Degas and Beyond
location: Harvard Art Museums, 32 Quincy St., Cambridge
fullLocation: Harvard Art Museums, 32 Quincy St., Cambridge
description: The Solomon Collection: Dürer to Degas and Beyond celebrates a significant recent bequest to the Harvard Art Museums from passionate collectors Arthur K. and Mariot F. Solomon. The exhibition spotlights over 135 works, including paintings, sculptures, drawings, and prints by some of the most significant artists from the Renaissance to the 20th century, and offers visitors an intimate view into the highly personal yet inherently collaborative nature of art collecting.

title: “The Things They Shared” Art Exhibition
location: CGIS South, 3rd floor, 1730 Cambridge St., Cambridge
fullLocation: CGIS South, 3rd floor, 1730 Cambridge St., Cambridge
description: “The Things They Shared” is an excerpt from Farrah Karapetian’s ongoing project, “Fieldwork.” It delves into the lives of cotton field workers in Uzbekistan, exploring their relationships with community, governance, subordination, personal freedom, and the natural and social environments they navigate. It also responds to representational histories — miming anthropological typology and the documentary photograph but privileging the personal experience of the worker rather than institutional narratives. Karapetian’s artistic approach is as integral to her message as is the subject matter itself. Cyanotype is one of photography’s original processes and requires only sun and water for its exposure and development, a priority in the context of industrially irrigated cotton fields that impact water ecologies. She uses a spray gun to deploy the cyanotype emulsion onto cotton rag substrate so as to clarify her voice, rather than purport to be objective. The cyanotype technique allows her to infuse softness into her photographic collages, creating layered, abstract images that speak directly to the essence of her subjects: cotton, the field, water, the sun, and the human touch.
host: Davis Center for Russian and Eurasian Studies

title: Illuminate: Contextualizing Asian American Women’s Stories through the Archives
location: Lia and William Poorvu Gallery, Schlesinger Library, 3 James St., Cambridge
locationVenue: Lia and William Poorvu Gallery, Schlesinger Library
fullLocation: Lia and William Poorvu Gallery, Schlesinger Library, 3 James St., Cambridge
description: "Illuminate: Contextualizing Asian American Women’s Stories through the Archives" spotlights the stories and lives of Asian American women whose collections are held in the Schlesinger Library. The featured materials provide viewers an opportunity to think critically and contextualize the often invisible and forgotten histories of Asian and Asian American women in the United States. At the same time, the exhibition examines how race, ethnicity, gender, citizenship, and migration impact the collective memory of a nation through primary sources.

title: Measuring Difference
location: Collection of Historical Scientific Instruments, 1 Oxford St., Cambridge
fullLocation: Collection of Historical Scientific Instruments, 1 Oxford St., Cambridge
description: Today, measurement is everywhere. We understand everything around us in inches, degrees, gallons, decibels, and more. But measurements are human inventions. It is through measures that we learn to see difference, to compare the world. In the Americas, colonial powers introduced new measurements to describe and exploit the “New World.” Existing ways of understanding and explaining the world and our relationship to others were displaced, cementing European measures as norms and tools of authority. Using examples from across the Americas, this exhibit illustrates what—and who—was measured, and how.

title: Virtual Case Discussion about Memorialization on Campus
description: Join the EdEthics initiative from the Harvard Graduate School of Education for a free online discussion of a brand-new case study, “Visual Veritas.” This nonfiction case examines the ethical challenges that arise when universities memorialize historically-complex figures through visual culture like portraits, statues, and busts. With an institutional commitment to truth and an increasingly diverse student body, what are the tradeoffs to consider when revisiting artistic representations of complex historical figures around campus? The discussion will take place over Zoom on Thursday, July 17, from 1-2:30pm Eastern Time. All Harvard students, faculty, staff, alumni, and affiliates are welcome. Email justice@gse.harvard.edu for a copy of the case and the Zoom link.
host: EdEthics at the Harvard Graduate School of Education

title: Addressing the Impact of Extreme Heat on Young Children
description: Excessive heat can impact young children’s development and health both in the moment and across the lifespan. Implementing strategies to reduce exposure to extreme heat benefits children, caregivers, and communities. Join us for a live conversation, Addressing the Impact of Extreme Heat on Young Children, on July 17 at 1 p.m. ET, as we explore how communities are working to reduce the effects of extreme heat on early childhood development.
host: Center on the Developing Child at Harvard University

title: All Stars: The Sensational History of Athletics as Entertainment
location: Houghton Library, Harvard Yard, Cambridge
fullLocation: Houghton Library, Harvard Yard, Cambridge

title: “The Things They Shared” Art Exhibition
location: CGIS South, 3rd floor, 1730 Cambridge St., Cambridge
fullLocation: CGIS South, 3rd floor, 1730 Cambridge St., Cambridge
description: “The Things They Shared” is an excerpt from Farrah Karapetian’s ongoing project, “Fieldwork.” It delves into the lives of cotton field workers in Uzbekistan, exploring their relationships with community, governance, subordination, personal freedom, and the natural and social environments they navigate. host: Davis Center for Russian and Eurasian Studies

title: Castaway: The Afterlife of Plastic
location: Peabody Museum of Archaeology & Ethnology, 11 Divinity Ave, Cambridge
fullLocation: Peabody Museum of Archaeology & Ethnology, 11 Divinity Ave, Cambridge
description: In this exhibition, the art collective TRES invites us to share their 2016 journey to document, collect, and photograph debris along the beaches of Australia. Evoking archaeology, marine biology, and cartography, their images summon us to more deeply engage with the natural vistas and objects they have encountered, and to examine and interpret them with fresh perspectives. TRES transports us with photographs of glowing orbs that resemble celestial spheres more than the bottle caps they once were. Making their way as garbage to Australia from as far away as China, these objects have been scarred by Bryozoa, tiny micro-organisms which can be seen in the display case in this exhibition. Now, plastic items such as these lay scattered about the otherwise pristine-appearing landscapes. The rhythmic flow of images challenges us to make sense of the terrain. With hand-drawn maps and charts, TRES attempts to bring order to a perplexing world, where plastic objects resemble organic ones, and “natural” landscapes bear unmistakable traces of human-made pollution.
host: Presented by the Peabody Museum of Archaeology & Ethnology and the Harvard Museums of Science & Culture.

title: Illuminate: Contextualizing Asian American Women’s Stories through the Archives
location: Lia and William Poorvu Gallery, Schlesinger Library, 3 James St., Cambridge
locationVenue: Lia and William Poorvu Gallery, Schlesinger Library
fullLocation: Lia and William Poorvu Gallery, Schlesinger Library, 3 James St., Cambridge

title: Sound of the Mountain
location: Harvard Film Archive, 24 Quincy St., Cambridge
fullLocation: Harvard Film Archive, 24 Quincy St., Cambridge
description: Uncharacteristic in Naruse’s oeuvre for its focus on a sympathetic aging patriarch, Sound of the Mountain nonetheless reveals itself gradually as a film about the women in his orbit. Shingo is a businessman who lives under one roof with his incorrigible son Shuichi, his estranged daughter Fusako, his loveless companion Yasuko, and the only person in the bunch with whom he shares any connection: Shuichi’s neglected wife, Kikuko.

title: Edvard Munch: Technically Speaking
location: Harvard Art Museums, 32 Quincy St., Cambridge
fullLocation: Harvard Art Museums, 32 Quincy St., Cambridge
description: Discover the experimental methods of Edvard Munch, who creatively explored materials and techniques across media. A dynamic collaboration between curatorial and conservation experts at the Harvard Art Museums, Edvard Munch: Technically Speaking offers rare insight into the Norwegian artist’s innovative techniques and the recurring themes across his paintings, woodcuts, lithographs, etchings, and combination prints. title: Double Take Exhibit Exploration
location: 26 Oxford St., Cambridge, GAZETTE CLASSIFICATION	Diversity and Inclusion, Exhibitions, Science, Special Events
locationCity: GAZETTE CLASSIFICATION	Diversity and Inclusion, Exhibitions, Science, Special Events
fullLocation: 26 Oxford St., Cambridge, GAZETTE CLASSIFICATION	Diversity and Inclusion, Exhibitions, Science, Special Events
description: There are thousands of objects on display across all four museums that make up the Harvard Museums of Science & Culture. It’s easy to miss things even if they’re right in front of you. This playful, self-paced Exhibit Exploration reveals some of our favorite details, stories, and specimens, all hidden in plain sight! Uncover the secret clue hidden within to win a prize. Explore the galleries with your friends or family. Perhaps you’ll find something else that causes you to do a double take! Pro tip: join us any Sunday–Friday 11:00 am–4:00 pm to access all four museums! Pick up Double Take Exhibit Exploration at museum front desks. Regular museum admission rates apply. Presented by the Peabody Museum of Archaeology & Ethnology, Harvard Museum of Natural History, Harvard Museum of the Ancient Near East, the Collection of Historical Scientific Instruments, and the Harvard Museums of Science & Culture.

title: Measuring Difference
location: Collection of Historical Scientific Instruments, 1 Oxford St., Cambridge
fullLocation: Collection of Historical Scientific Instruments, 1 Oxford St., Cambridge
description: Today, measurement is everywhere. We understand everything around us in inches, degrees, gallons, decibels, and more. But measurements are human inventions. title: A Wife’s Heart
location: Harvard Film Archive, 24 Quincy St., Cambridge
fullLocation: Harvard Film Archive, 24 Quincy St., Cambridge
description: Husband and wife Shinji and Kiyoko want to open a café with all the money they have when Shinji’s overbearing mother pressures them to help out the favored, once-successful brother, now down on his luck. Meanwhile, Kiyoko’s business ambitions are encouraged by a handsome bank clerk whose charm and support serve as a salve to her increasingly stressful homelife.

title: Yearning
location: Harvard Film Archive, 24 Quincy St., Cambridge
fullLocation: Harvard Film Archive, 24 Quincy St., Cambridge
description: War widow Reiko finds herself at odds with her late husband's family. His sisters seek to fire her from the family business, and her brother-in-law Koji demands that she address his love for her. Not only is Yearning a paragon of Naruse's command of glances and gestures, but it is also distinct for its union of repressed sexual desire, postwar family dynamics and the brutality of corporate business as entwined forces hindering women's independence.

title: Science Book Talk — Lisa S. Gardiner, "Reefs of Time: What Fossils Reveal about Coral Survival"
location: Cambridge Public Library, 449 Broadway, Cambridge
fullLocation: Cambridge Public Library, 449 Broadway, Cambridge
description: A popular science writer, geoscientist, and educator Lisa S. Gardiner will talk about her book, "Reefs of Time," on how fossilized reefs hold clues to the survival of corals in the Anthropocene.
host: Harvard Book Store, Harvard Division of Science, Harvard Library, and Cambridge Public Library

title: Anzukko / Little Peach
location: 24 Quincy St., Cambridge, GAZETTE CLASSIFICATION	Diversity and Inclusion, Film
locationCity: GAZETTE CLASSIFICATION	Diversity and Inclusion, Film
fullLocation: 24 Quincy St., Cambridge, GAZETTE CLASSIFICATION	Diversity and Inclusion, Film
description: Naruse’s women are imperiled by life itself because they are so close to its everyday rhythms and so exposed to the chance encounters of the street. A masterpiece of Naruse’s elliptical and unemphatic fifties style, Anzukko is built largely on the movements of the heroine, Kyoko, through various streets, toward and away from her parents’ house.

fullLocation: Houghton Library, Harvard Yard, Cambridge
description: 2025 marks the 300th anniversary of a technology associated with the computer age, but with roots in the Industrial Revolution. In 1725, French silk weaver Basile Bouchon invented the use of a paper tape with punched holes to automate the work of a loom. By the 19th century, punchcard-controlled looms produced sophisticated textiles, including fabric "pages" woven from silk to simulate the leaves of a medieval manuscript. Computing pioneer Charles Babbage first envisioned adapting punched cards to computing; in the early computer age, they were the primary means for data entry and processing. In "Punched Card Methods in Scientific Computation," Wallace Eckert shared his work using punched cards to perform complex calculations such as determining the orbits of planets.

title: The Solomon Collection: Dürer to Degas and Beyond
location: Harvard Art Museums, 32 Quincy St., Cambridge
fullLocation: Harvard Art Museums, 32 Quincy St., Cambridge
description: The Solomon Collection: Dürer to Degas and Beyond celebrates a significant recent bequest to the Harvard Art Museums from passionate collectors Arthur K. and Mariot F. Solomon. The exhibition spotlights over 135 works, including paintings, sculptures, drawings, and prints by some of the most significant artists from the Renaissance to the 20th century, and offers visitors an intimate view into the highly personal yet inherently collaborative nature of art collecting.

title: “The Things They Shared” Art Exhibition
location: CGIS South, 3rd floor, 1730 Cambridge St., Cambridge
fullLocation: CGIS South, 3rd floor, 1730 Cambridge St., Cambridge
description: “The Things They Shared” is an excerpt from Farrah Karapetian’s ongoing project, “Fieldwork.” It delves into the lives of cotton field workers in Uzbekistan, exploring their relationships with community, governance, subordination, personal freedom, and the natural and social environments they navigate. It also responds to representational histories — miming anthropological typology and the documentary photograph but privileging the personal experience of the worker rather than institutional narratives. Karapetian’s artistic approach is as integral to her message as is the subject matter itself. Cyanotype is one of photography’s original processes and requires only sun and water for its exposure and development, a priority in the context of industrially irrigated cotton fields that impact water ecologies. She uses a spray gun to deploy the cyanotype emulsion onto cotton rag substrate so as to clarify her voice, rather than purport to be objective. The cyanotype technique allows her to infuse softness into her photographic collages, creating layered, abstract images that speak directly to the essence of her subjects: cotton, the field, water, the sun, and the human touch.
host: Davis Center for Russian and Eurasian Studies

title: Castaway: The Afterlife of Plastic
location: Peabody Museum of Archaeology & Ethnology, 11 Divinity Ave, Cambridge
fullLocation: Peabody Museum of Archaeology & Ethnology, 11 Divinity Ave, Cambridge
description: In this exhibition, the art collective TRES invites us to share their 2016 journey to document, collect, and photograph debris along the beaches of Australia. Evoking archaeology, marine biology, and cartography, their images summon us to more deeply engage with the natural vistas and objects they have encountered, and to examine and interpret them with fresh perspectives. TRES transports us with photographs of glowing orbs that resemble celestial spheres more than the bottle caps they once were. Making their way as garbage to Australia from as far away as China, these objects have been scarred by Bryozoa, tiny micro-organisms which can be seen in the display case in this exhibition. Now, plastic items such as these lay scattered about the otherwise pristine-appearing landscapes. The rhythmic flow of images challenges us to make sense of the terrain. With hand-drawn maps and charts, TRES attempts to bring order to a perplexing world, where plastic objects resemble organic ones, and “natural” landscapes bear unmistakable traces of human-made pollution.
host: Presented by the Peabody Museum of Archaeology & Ethnology and the Harvard Museums of Science & Culture.

title: Illuminate: Contextualizing Asian American Women’s Stories through the Archives
location: Lia and William Poorvu Gallery, Schlesinger Library, 3 James St., Cambridge
locationVenue: Lia and William Poorvu Gallery, Schlesinger Library
fullLocation: Lia and William Poorvu Gallery, Schlesinger Library, 3 James St., Cambridge
description: "Illuminate: Contextualizing Asian American Women’s Stories through the Archives" spotlights the stories and lives of Asian American women whose collections are held in the Schlesinger Library. The featured materials provide viewers an opportunity to think critically and contextualize the often invisible and forgotten histories of Asian and Asian American women in the United States. At the same time, the exhibition examines how race, ethnicity, gender, citizenship, and migration impact the collective memory of a nation through primary sources.

title: Measuring Difference
location: Collection of Historical Scientific Instruments, 1 Oxford St., Cambridge
fullLocation: Collection of Historical Scientific Instruments, 1 Oxford St., Cambridge
description: Today, measurement is everywhere. We understand everything around us in inches, degrees, gallons, decibels, and more. But measurements are human inventions. It is through measures that we learn to see difference, to compare the world. In the Americas, colonial powers introduced new measurements to describe and exploit the “New World.” Existing ways of understanding and explaining the world and our relationship to others were displaced, cementing European measures as norms and tools of authority. Using examples from across the Americas, this exhibit illustrates what—and who—was measured, and how.

title: Farmers' Market at Harvard
location: Science Center Plaza, 1 Oxford St., Cambridge
fullLocation: Science Center Plaza, 1 Oxford St., Cambridge
description: Grab your shopping bag and join us at the market every Tuesday through October 28th, 11:30 a.m. - 5:30 p.m. and help support the vital local farmers and food artisans who ensure we have fresh, healthy food! Stop by for lemonade topped with local fruit and herbs, mushrooms, early summer produce, freshly baked bread, olives, cookies, iced coffee, and more! The market accepts SNAP with a weekly maximum SNAP Match of $15. Participating vendors also accept HIP, WIC and Senior FMNP Coupons.

Lectures • Virtual Radcliffe Book Talks
Tuesday, August 5, 2025
12 PM ET
Online on Zoom
 
 
The fourth and final installment in our series features Geraldine Brooks RI ’06, author of Memorial Days: A Memoir (Viking, 2025). A Pulitzer Prize–winning novelist, nonfiction writer, and former foreign correspondent, Brooks blends personal narrative and historical reflection in this meditation on grief, war, and memory, written in the wake of the death of her husband, the writer Tony Horwitz RI ’06, also a Pulitzer-prize winner.
 
 
 
For more information and to register, please visit:

title: Youth in Public Health Symposium, Dongguan 2025
dateTime: Monday, August 4 2025 at 9:00 AM EDT to Friday, August 8 2025 at 5:00 PM EDT Add To Google Calendar | iCal/Outlook
location: Tsinglan School: https://www.tsinglan.cn/en/index
description:
ABOUT YPHS
The Youth in Public Health Symposium (YPHS) was established in 2016 by Dr. Liming Liang, a Professor of Statistical Genetics in the Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics. The symposium aims to expose high school students to different fields of public health and provide practical examples of the knowledge they learn in science classes. This helps students learn how rigorous research is done in public health and make informed decisions about their future college majors. YPHS incorporates nano-courses that allow students to connect with leading researchers, acquire fundamental knowledge, and develop community projects in public health areas. For the symposiums from previous years, please click on the links (2024 Dongguan Camp, 2024 Boston Camp, 2023 Shanghai Camp, 2023 Boston Camp, 2020 Online Forum, 2019 Boston Camp, 2018 Boston Camp).
 
ABOUT THE DONGGUAN 2025 PROGRAM
This summer school in Dongguan, Guangdong Province, China, is part of the YPHS programs designed specifically for high school students. The event will be held from August 4th to 8th, 2025, at Tsinglan School.
As a non-profit initiative, this program offers participants the opportunity to:
- Engage with world-class scholars: Work closely with Harvard University professors and current doctoral students to explore cutting-edge topics in public health and learn about academic and career pathways in the field.
- Collaborate with talented peers: Join a community of outstanding high school students to conduct group-based, project-style research, delve into public health knowledge, and enjoy the excitement of scientific inquiry.
- Apply knowledge to real-world challenges: Investigate public health issues, and use scientific knowledge to create meaningful solutions, shaping yourself into a future leader in public health.
- Receive formal recognition: Earn a certificate of completion issued by a Harvard University professor.
- Expand your global experience: Outstanding participants may be invited to the Youth in Public Health Symposium in Boston in Spring 2026.
 
Program Highlights
- Pre-program preparation: Students will receive curated reading and preparatory materials in June 2025, designed by the Harvard team.
- Core and elective courses: A flexible course system combining essential public health topics and personalized electives, allowing students to tailor their learning experience.
- Research and presentations: Under the guidance of Harvard doctoral students, participants will apply their knowledge to address pressing public health challenges, culminating in research proposals, oral presentations, and academic poster displays.
 
Recruitment Details
- Enrollment: 100 students
- Eligibility: Students entering grades 9–12 in the 2025–2026 academic year with a strong academic foundation, a keen interest in public health, and proficiency in English.
- Application: Students are required to submit an application form. More details and specific requirements can be found at here.
host: Interdisciplinary Discussion on Disease and Health, a Harvard Griffin GSAS Student Group

title: GSAS Peer Mentor Training
dateTime: Friday, September 12 2025 at 9:00 AM EDT to Friday, September 12 2025 at 1:00 PM EDT Add To Google Calendar | iCal/Outlook
location: 201 Common Room
description:
The Office of Student Services is hosting the GSAS Peer Mentoring Training for current and prospective peer mentors within Harvard Griffin GSAS. In this training, participants will have the opportunity to engage in listening skills and coaching strategies while learning about vital university resources that support the graduate student journey.
The peer mentor training will take place at the GSAS Student Center at Lehman Hall on Friday, September 12 from 9:00 am-1:00 p.m.
The Student Center welcomes individuals with disabilities to participate in its programs and activities. If you would like to request accommodations for events or have questions, please contact  stucenter@fas.harvard.edu or 614-495-2255 in advance of the event.
Questions about the event? Email stuserv@fas.harvard.edu 
Perks
 Free Food
